name: building construction, hostel | building, hostel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20167/documentation

This dataset represents a tourist accommodation facility located in Barranco, Lima, Peru. The case study hotel is classed as hostel. It was first opened in 2002 although the building where the hostel resides was constructed in early 1900s. Prior to becoming a hostel, the building was used as residence. The hostel has capacity of 56 beds and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): double (2), triple (1), family (1) and shared use (8). The hostel has 1 floor which hosts a lobby, a restaurant and a bar. Laundry is outsourced and there is no parking available on site. The load bearing structure of hotel building is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork. The hostel occupies a total area of 700 m2 where the building itself occupies the plot of 550 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hostel is 54% which is equal to 11037 guest nights per year. The hostel"s occupancy is somewhat lower than the country"s average of 66%; (Source: Hotel News Now 2015. The state of Peru"s tourism, hotels. Available from: http://www.hotelnewsnow.biz/Articles/27650/The-state-of-Perus-tourism-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018) which can in part be explained by the over-saturated market of hostels in Lima. Lima is a popular destination with backpackers and budget travellers who visit Lima as a place for a short stay prior to exploring the interior of Peru. This has triggered development of the hostel sector in Lima with subsequent enhanced competition. 

This dataset is modelled to include the inputs for the construction of a hotel building. This includes:energy and water used in construction, land transformation, building structure and outer building shell, inner walls, roofs, ceiling and windows, doors, floors, finishing and painting, bathroom equipment. Activities include hotel building construction with lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. Maintenance is included only through the consideration of the lifetime of the different exchanges. For example, windows are assumed to have a lifetime of 35 years, therefore the exchange amount is multiplied by 75years / 35 years=2.14. Hotel building foundation is included in the form of estimates based on the hotel area and construction practices in Peru. 

Activities end with 1 unit of hotel building, including maintenance. Due to data availability, the following building construction processes have been excluded: cables, gutter, drains, ventilation.
category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is based in Lima, Peru.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The level of technology is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of construction, the amounts of input material are calculated based on usage across all instances within the hotel building.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

flow.name: building, hostel

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Used here in place of all varnishes. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls. Assuming 1 liter of paint is required to paint 10m2 and weighs 1.5 kg. Source:  BQ 2018. Wall painting calculator. Available from: https://www.diy.com/help-advice/wall-painting-calculator/Dev_npcart_100008.art Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of 5 years which is equivalent to the period of major refurbishments in hotels. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19(17-18), 1917-1930. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste paint on wall.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Assuming that 0.5 kl per 1 m2 of floor area (GFA) is required in building construction. Source: Crawford et al. 2005. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. Value double checked in McCormack, et al. 2007.

Reference:

Crawford, Robert and Treloar, Graham 2005, An assessment of the energy and water embodied in commercial building construction, in Australian Life Cycle Assessment Conference (4th : 2005 : Novotel, Sydney, N.S.W.), Australian Life Cycle Assessment Society, Sydney, N.S.W., pp. 1-10.

McCormack, et al. 2007. Modelling direct and indirect water requirements of construction. Building research & information. 35(2), 156-162.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Assumed thickness of steel 0.7 mm. Source: MCRMA 2004. PROFILED METAL ROOFING DESIGN GUIDE. MCRMA Technical Paper No. 6. Available from: http://www.mcrma.co.uk/pdf/mcrma_t06.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed density of steel 7850 kg/m3. Source: The Calculator site 2018. Metal converter. Available from: https://www.thecalculatorsite.com/conversions/substances/metal.php Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to iron scrap.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Used here in place of the floor material. No data on the type of flooring was provided by the case study hotel so PVC was used as proxy. This is because PVC flooring is most cost-effective for hotels. Source: Mikulski 2015. TOP HOSPITALITY FLOORING OPTIONS FOR HOTELS. Available from: http://www.businessflooring.net/blog/top-hospitality-flooring-options-for-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018. Combined of all instances of use across the building. Assumed density of PVC 2.3 kg/m2. Source: The colour flooring company 2018. VINYL FLOORING TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS. Available from: https://www.colourflooring.co.uk/pages/vinyl-flooring-technical-specifications Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of PVC floors is 40 years. Source: Bowyer et al. 2009. LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENT OF FLOORING MATERIALS A GUIDE TO INTELLIGENT SELECTION. Doviteil Partners. Available from: http://www.dovetailinc.org/report_pdfs/2009/dovetailfloors0809.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018.  In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to waste PVC.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Used here in place of adobe reported by the hotel as concrete represents a more conventional construction material. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls (513m3). The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. 

Additionally the concrete for foundations is accounted for (50m3). Estimated value based on the hotel area and construction practices in Peru. The foundation is assumed to be 200 m long, 0.5 m wide and 0.5 m deep. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste concrete.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). This flow represents ceramic washing basin and ceramic toilet seat. The hostel has 6 washing basins and 6 toilet seats. Washing basins are assumed to weigh 15kg (information taken from IKEA (2018) for the product "TÃ–RNVIKEN Countertop wash-basin", source retrieved from: http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/products/washstands-taps/wash-basins/t%C3%B6rnviken-countertop-wash-basin-white-art-90291518/, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Toilet seats are assumed to weigh 35kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product "COOKE & LEWIS FABIENNE CLOSE-COUPLED TOILET WITH SOFT CLOSE SEAT", source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-fabienne-close-coupled-toilet-with-soft-close-seat/1142804_BQ.prd?B/R_Toilets_C_CT, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Assumed service life of 40 years. Source: Cobut et al. 2015. The environmental footprint of interior wood doors in non-residential buildings - part 1: life cycle assessment. Journal of Cleaner Production, 109, 232-246. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to used door, outer, wood-glass.
